description: From Middle Dutch schampen (“slip away”), from Old French escamper (“to run away, to make one's escape”), from Vulgar Latin *excampāre.

entries.meaning: A rascal, swindler, or rogue; a ne'er-do-well.
examples: Synonyms: swindler, rogue; see also Thesaurus:troublemaker

entries.meaning: A mischievous person, especially a playful, impish youngster.
examples: My nephew is a little scamp who likes to leave lighted firecrackers under the lawnchairs of his dozing elders.
While walking home from the bar, he was set upon by a bunch of scamps who stole his hat.

description: Perhaps related to sense 1, but influenced by the later attested skimp; however, compare Icelandic skamta (“to dole out, to stint”), which is related to skammur (“short”).

verbs.description: scamp (third-person singular simple present scamps, present participle scamping, simple past and past participle scamped)

entries.meaning: (dated) To skimp; to do something in a skimpy or slipshod fashion.
examples: His work was always first-rate. There was no scamping about it. Everything that he did was thoroughly good and honest.
It did not matter that the scamp (simple illustrative line-drawing) it contained could have been done in the pub the night before.
